Mr President, Commissioner, honourable Members, it is not my intention, nor that of my group, which has supported and wanted this debate, to transfer to the European level the diatribe of Italian internal politics.

The issue of freedom of information concerns all of us, it concerns the European Union, which can and must regulate the matter at the community level in order to counter political and economic conditioning and to ensure a real pluralism of information.

The Italian anomaly, where the prime minister is also the owner of some of the most important private networks, consists precisely in the existence of a dangerous entanglement between media, political and economic powers.

It is precisely for this reason that we are calling for a European regulatory intervention, an intervention that, far from being an act of anti-italianism, serves to protect pluralism of information, avoiding concentrations and conflicts of interest.

For this reason, today we ask the Commission to intervene as soon as possible, as this Parliament has also requested in the past, to equip the European Union with common rules to protect the freedom of information for all European citizens.

I must admit that when we talk about the fight against terrorism, discussing only intelligence and technology, I always have the impression that we are reluctant to examine the issue in an inadequate way, as if we wanted to cure a disease by concentrating only on its symptoms and not on its causes.
Is it not time to address the problem of terrorism by looking at the heart of the matter, rather than limiting ourselves to its external phenomenology?

Addressing the heart of the problem means, for example, becoming aware that terrorism is also the direct manifestation of the incapacity or unwillingness of ethnic groups to integrate into the European cultural fabric.

Thank you, Mr. President. The closure of the negotiations with Croatia by 2010 is a possible objective, and the report Svolta underlines in a balanced way the progress and the steps still to be taken.

React, that is, abandon the celebratory tones of Euro propaganda to address in a concrete way the problems that afflict the citizens of the EU, ensuring a direct connection between the world of training and the needs of the market and the territory, requalifying among young people the perception of manual professions.

Evolvere, that is, to make the strategy of the EU twenty twenty a positive synthesis between the requests of companies and those of workers in favor of a labor market in which both the flexibility and security of contractual forms respond to the instability of market demand.

Thank you, Mr. President. The proposal on the rights of passengers travelling by bus aims to improve and protect passengers, especially the disabled or those with reduced mobility.
This is the first regulation on passenger rights by bus and should guarantee passengers as it does in the railway and air sectors.
The position in the second reading is aimed at establishing a series of rights for passengers who decide to travel by bus.

I agree with the rapporteur Canciang, whom I thank for the excellent work done, and I believe that the scope of application of the regulation should be modified, excluding regional services when they are integrated with urban and suburban services.
It would be right and necessary to guarantee the rights of passengers in the event of accidents, cancellations or delays to departure, as had already been decided in the first reading by Parliament.

Equally important is the issue of information on passenger rights. It would be useful, in fact, to provide passengers with information on the coincidences with other modes of transport. This will also ensure the dialogue between passenger transport services by bus and those by rail.

As for the disabled and people with reduced mobility, it is necessary to guarantee maximum protection and I would propose the term of twenty-four hours instead of forty-eight in order to request assistance as well as greater guarantees for compensation and replacement of the tools that ensure the mobility of people with different abilities in the event of loss or damage.
Furthermore, taking into account the needs of passengers with reduced mobility, any architectural barrier should be eliminated and existing infrastructure should be improved to make it accessible.
This regulation aims to improve the competitiveness of the bus sector, promote interoperability, but above all, to improve the travel conditions of passengers.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to thank the rapporteur Sterckx, who has done an excellent job on this report, which deals with how to extend free movement in the maritime sector for navigation within the European Union.
I agree with the rapporteur on the purpose of this directive, which is to exempt all maritime goods transports within the European Union from unnecessary administrative formalities.

In fact, to have a European maritime space without borders, it is not only important that the various competent authorities cooperate satisfactorily, but also that the various simplification systems are applied at the same time.
This is necessary to ensure the smooth functioning of the entire European maritime space without borders, to make sea transport of goods more attractive and used in the best possible way.

The harmonization of administrative procedures among Member States will allow for smoother navigation between the various ports of the European Union and will boost sea trade, which currently accounts for less than ten percent of the total.
To date, navigation continues to be hindered by the administrative formalities imposed on it.
The electronic systems should therefore be put into operation as soon as possible, because it would allow for a faster data exchange system.

Furthermore, interoperability is important to have a real administrative simplification. In fact, the sending of information via email is not entirely efficient, it is useless if the information systems are not interoperable from a technical point of view.
As for the language, I believe that the use of a common language would certainly benefit European maritime navigation.
In this way, the communication would be more efficient, causing less confusion and fewer administrative delays.

Mr President, honourable Members, Commissioner, with this measure we want to strengthen and rationalise the European Union's drug surveillance system.
These are the ambitious objectives that the Mckeeva report proposes, which are respectively modifying the 726 and 2001/83 directives.
Thanks to a concerted, efficient and effective work between the European Council and Parliament and the same parliamentary committees competent for the matter, it was possible to reach a compromise.
To discuss today a proposal that aims to improve the Community's drug surveillance system and to perfect the consistent and multi-decade activity of the European Union in this sector.

Simplification, transparency and rationalization can be considered the key points of these two reports, which propose measures aimed at ensuring the best possible protection of public health based on harmonized standards throughout Europe.

In fact, it refers to a wide range of interventions that go from a better definition of roles and responsibilities of the main national and supranational subjects concerned, to a new and more consciously active involvement of the patient, to which we are referring.

The European Union recognizes a fundamental role in the system, the strengthening of transparency of information regarding the safety of medicines, the simplification of communication, registration and evaluation activities of alleged negative side effects.
The current drug surveillance system must be improved, also thanks to a closer collaboration at European, national and regional levels.
An effective participation at all three levels will in fact ensure a fruitful exchange of information regarding the collateral reactions of the drugs.
The new pharmacovigilance system will be able to ensure a high level of shared and secure information in favor of patients, national authorities and health care workers.

The first fundamental is that of its renationalization. It would be a serious step backwards.

We expect the Commission to go in this direction.
Dear colleagues, the road to a Europe that is fit for women is still long and difficult.

The greater integration of women is not only a moral value, but also a strategic objective for the sustainability of the much publicized European social model, which continues to fail me due to the lack of results.

During 2009, the European Commission presented a proposal to amend Regulation 1905 of 2006, which establishes a financial instrument for cooperation for the development of the Mediterranean.

Proposta da noi accettata.
But the cooperation and development regulation also contains the implementation standards for the European Union's development policy.
These rules provide that when the Commission must provide funding, it must follow the procedures of Comitology.

This means that Parliament has the power to examine these funding proposals and, in case the Commission exceeds its own competences, Parliament can then adopt resolutions in order to ask the Commission to change the decisions in question.

Only from 2006 to the present day, Parliament has considered that in at least twelve cases the Commission had exceeded its powers of execution, but only in three of these cases the Commission has in fact modified or withdrawn its proposal for a decision.
After the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, the Development Commission proposed to apply the procedure for delegated acts provided for in Article 290 of the Lisbon Treaty.
The adoption of these procedures would mean that, at least in the strategic funding decisions that the European Commission must adopt, Parliament would have a more relevant role.
In fact, according to the Lisbon Treaty, in some well-defined cases, the Parliament can delegate to the Commission the power to take strategic decisions. But what could these decisions be?
In our opinion, the choice of countries to which the European Union should provide development aid.

It is a choice that lies with the legislator. So which sectors should be given priority in funding? Education, health, environmental protection, good governance, and the development of small businesses.
And how to ensure transparency in the management of development aid?
These are the choices, the matters in which the European Parliament should play a more important role than it has in the past.
It is here that the legislator must give precise instructions to the executive.

Thank you, Mr. President. To date, access to employment is regulated only for some specific categories of citizens of third countries.
In fact, not everyone benefits from the general principle of equal treatment in access to employment.

In this context, the European Union must act to ensure equal treatment for both citizens of third countries who legally reside within Member States and beneficiaries of refugee or international protection status, in accordance with Directive 83/1999 of 29 April 2004.
It is necessary to avoid a growing demand, for example, for seasonal staff only because they are paid less or have different, lower costs than a European citizen recruited for the same job.

For example, we must avoid the risk that many multinationals will move their headquarters to countries such as Morocco or Turkey and send their employees to work in European subsidiaries because it is cheaper.
For reasons of social justice, ensuring the same treatment of European citizens in terms of remuneration, working conditions and social security is fundamental.
For this reason, I believe it is right that seasonal workers, those detached, refugees and self-employed workers are included in this directive.
Making a difference will become extremely dangerous.

Thank you, Mr. President. Honorable colleagues, according to the estimates of international organizations and law enforcement agencies, the trafficking of human beings is now the second most profitable source of income for organized crime worldwide, after drug trafficking.
It is estimated that about thirty million people are victims of organ trafficking, prostitution and forced labour.

This means that, first of all, the fight against this criminal phenomenon of vast proportions is a battle for the safety of our citizens, against clandestinity, against the crime that generates crime.
In the face of such a phenomenon, Europe must rightly put in place drastic measures against those who exploit human beings in various ways.

In the fight against this phenomenon, it is necessary to cooperate between member countries and between the police agencies, but above all, the certainty of the penalties for the traffickers. Let us remember, however, that many people are victims.

They are exploited because in their home countries they do not find dignified living conditions, they live in poverty and despair and are ready to do anything to leave their land for the promise of a better life that will not be realized.

Europe, then, in addition to preventing crime and protecting the victims of trafficking, must commit itself more and with greater scrupulousness to ensure that these people can find in their countries acceptable living conditions.
Acceptable. Let's help them at home. It must be the inspiring principle of European political action, so that our efforts are directed, in addition to repression, also to prevention.

Thank you, Mr. President. The situation that Campania, and in particular the city of Naples, has been experiencing for some time is unfortunately well known to the whole world, and the European Union has had to deal with the issue several times.

Faced with such a paradoxical situation, from the third world, I therefore ask the Commission what consequences Italy will face from the point of view of community law and what economic sanctions will eventually be imposed on Italy in the event that the crisis of waste in the countryside does not find a definitive solution in the near future.

I also ask if the Commission can provide in detail the data relating to the European funds that have been managed so far by the Campania region for the creation of an integrated system for the collection and disposal of waste.
You see, Commissioner, usually when we talk about emergency, we talk about dramatic, extreme situations that, however, find a solution in reasonable time.
When a so-called emergency lasts for more than fifteen years, obviously there is something that does not work.

The Italian government in recent years has tried to do everything possible to solve the long-standing issue of the waste collection and disposal cycle, but evidently if today the streets of Naples are clogged with tons of waste.
The fault is mainly to be attributed to the local authorities, the Campania authorities, and their total incapacity or lack of will to take action to find a solution.

It is clear and absolutely beyond any doubt that the conditions in which Naples and Campania are facing are due to the latifronza that has characterized for many years the management of the waste cycle in the municipalities, provinces and regions.
If the duty of separate waste collection, the first and indispensable element of a functioning waste management plan, is not fulfilled, it cannot be the fault of the central government.

If the Italian government had to send the army, it happened a few weeks ago, but other times in the past, to replace hundreds of suddenly and simultaneously sick netherkins, obviously it cannot be the fault of the central government.

If the emergency has hit Naples, while in the rest of Italy things are going quite differently, for example in the region of Veneto, where the waste collection has been done for years without problems and with a very high recycling rate, it means that the responsibility for the emergency falls on the.

On the regional policy and local administrators, and above all on the heavy collusion with the underworld, which has always sought and obtained huge profits from the waste business, thanks to the infiltration of the Camorra into politics and local administrations.
After the lies of the Berlusconi government, which started in 2008, telling Italians that the waste problem was over, is it good for the European Union?
To block funds to Italy until a cycle of eco-compatible waste is presented that is based on recycling and composting.

Thank you, Mr. President. To date, the recommendations adopted by the General Commission for the Mediterranean Sea have been received in the Community legislation on a provisional basis, through annual regulations on fishing possibilities.
These concern the conservation, management, exploitation, control and commercialization measures for fish and aquaculture products in the Mediterranean.
The permanent nature of such recommendations, however, requires a more stable legal instrument for their reception in Community law.
It is therefore appropriate to receive the recommendations on the object through a single legislative act to which future recommendations can be added.
Today we have done this and this will improve the certainty of the law, at the same time constituting an important step towards simplification.
At this point, the parties to the CGMPM have the obligation to ensure full implementation of measures agreed upon following the High Authority's decision.

The urgent transposition was therefore necessary in order to make such international measures directly applicable to natural and legal persons at Community level and to ensure the certainty of the law.

Thank you, Mr. President. The Fukushima accident continues to produce very serious consequences, with the loss of radioactive water in the sea six, five hundred times above the legal limits.
The risk that food products are contaminated is high.
Europe has established very strict controls, but this concerns exclusively fresh products.
No standard has been issued to protect processed products, especially canned fish.
We import three hundred and seventy thousand tons of canned tuna. The main suppliers are the countries of South East Asia, which import fish from Japan.
This means that canned fish imported into Europe could contain Japanese fish.
It is fundamental and urgent to provide precise information about the place of origin.
Today, in fact, consumers know where the box was produced, but not where the fish was caught.

The Commission recently acknowledged this and plans to fill this gap with the reform of the common fisheries policy, which however will not come into force before two years, just as the Sommer report, which is being discussed in this plenary, will not be effective before three years.
We should not create alarmism, but consumers have the right to urgent and transparent information.
The Commission must intervene as soon as possible.

Mr President, honourable Members, Mr Representative of the Council and Commissioner, first of all I would like to positively greet, as other Members have done, the anti-corruption package that the European Commission approved last June 6th.
Corruption is a transnational phenomenon and to fight it, European-scale measures are necessary.

Come dare loro torto?
In many Member States, there is a lack of political will to fight corruption. Just think that there are still European countries that have not signed the United Nations Convention against Corruption.

If we think about the devastating impact of corruption on democratic processes, on citizens' rights and on trust in the rule of law, it is clear that the national measures of counteraction adopted by Member States so far are insufficient to contain an expanding phenomenon.

It is the European Union that must give a unified and strong response, especially now, in the midst of an unprecedented economic crisis that is weighing on people's lives, on the maintenance of social security and welfare systems, and on the ability of institutions to guarantee essential services.

In particular, we cannot talk about the fight against corruption if we are not able to adopt at least minimum standards for the definition of the crime of corruption, of which there is no trace in the package just passed.
The same applies to the definition of uniform parameters to measure the extent of the phenomenon in the Member States, essential to prepare an effective response.

I believe that a common and very strong sensitivity has developed towards this issue, also because we must remember that we live in an era that is truly characterized by an exponential increase in disasters.
The numbers, if we look at them in their rawness, are very eloquent. The number of disasters in the world has quintupled if we think that in 1975.
Seventy eight catastrophic events had been recorded, while today we are facing almost four hundred calamitous events a year.

In the last twenty years, unfortunately, the victims of these disasters have been ninety thousand and more than twenty nine million people have been affected by disasters, while the economic losses amount to two hundred and eleven billion euros.
It is evident that we are facing a phenomenon, phenomena of such dimensions that require a stronger response, a more effective response, and a really strong commitment on our part.
We all have in our eyes the images of the earthquake in Haiti, the floods in Pakistan, what happened in Japan.
Europe itself sees on its territory every year sudden floods, fires, and we remember the cloud of ashes followed by the eruption of the Icelandic volcano.

I am very grateful for the work that you have done with this report.

Dear colleagues, Finland and the Netherlands have taken the chair of the Council for a very simple reason. Bulgaria and Romania are not able to guarantee an effective border control today, and they are the scene of a widespread corruption that involves the political class and organized crime.
Thinking of it this way, it is not the parties and populist movements that are the problem, but the EUPOL in its 2010 report on organized crime.
There is no populist propaganda, but a serious security problem.

In the event that Bulgaria were to join the Schengen area at this time, the police and security organizations predict that the Bulgarian borders, especially the maritime ones, would become an easy target for Turkish and Eastern European crime and that Bulgaria and Romania would become the crossroads of human and drug trafficking.

It is natural that some Member States have many reservations about the real capacity of Bulgaria and Romania to ensure effective border controls against organized crime and corruption, and it is therefore absolutely natural that they opposed their entry into Schengen.
Allowing it now means opening the way to transnational crime and opening a loophole in the European borders, precisely where there is a very strong migratory pressure from Turkey.
There are many reasons to oppose, and Europe cannot ignore them.
I therefore ask to know what the intentions of the Commission and the Council are in this delicate matter, which in my opinion has been treated so far with.
Sufficienza e senza tener conto dei pericoli che l'ingresso di Bulgaria e Romania comporterebbe, a detta degli organismi competenti in materia di sicurezza e criminalità internazionale.

In my opinion, the Commission and the Council should postpone the entry of these two countries into Schengen and give the OK only when there is reasonable certainty that the entry of Bulgaria and Romania will not have repercussions on the security of European citizens.

Thank you, Mr. President. Phosphates present in detergents for washing machines end up in the water systems, in rivers, streams and lakes in Europe.

Phosphorus determines an acceleration of the reproduction of the various forms of life. Consequently, algae and other rapidly developing plant species proliferate disproportionately when there is an increase in the presence of phosphorus in an aquatic environment.
This excessive growth of algae takes oxygen from other living organisms. It can also produce toxins, destroying plant and animal species, thus reducing the quality of the water itself.

I have therefore expressed my vote in favour of the text voted this day, because to purify the European water heritage it is desirable to reduce the amount of phosphorus that is poured into the waters of our continent.

A robust development of the cooperative dimension in the economy has resulted in an increase in employment, a more qualified workforce, and a more balanced redistribution of wealth produced.

The unemployment of millions of Europeans does not depend on the generous assistance offered by the European Fund for Globalization. Under the Lisbon Treaty, the European Parliament has become a full-fledged institutional subject in the field of security policies and therefore has the right to actively and decisively participate in the priorities of the internal security strategy and the security model of the Union.

Mr President, with the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the foundations have been laid for the development of integrated criminal law in Community law.

While emphasizing the importance of mutual recognition of harmonization of protection standards, the presumption of innocence, it is good to emphasize how the law must be extremely clear and easily understandable, in order to make it clear to all which actions constitute a crime or not.

Mr. Commissioner, today he has asked Europe for a new task of coordinating industrial policies and even the most severe supporters of autonomy and private initiative are calling for the exercise of this role.
Without a greater Europeanization of national strategies, even under the profile of occupational protection, the current crisis will not be overcome and there will be no recovery.
The car crisis is not only overproduction, it is dramatic loss of employment.
But the crisis now seems structural and concerns the very fate of the car, the product, as it is today.
We want to keep the car industry in Europe and we do not want to disperse the existing know-how, the professional skills.
We therefore ask that a major project of restructuring and relaunch be initiated, and that it be done in a short time, because the costs are proportional to the time.
The restructuring cannot be the result of fragmented national decisions or individual companies.
It is necessary at least to try to coordinate and guide this painful process at the community level, putting the interested parties around the table with social dialogue.
The producers, trade unions and governments of individual countries, offering support for research, innovation, human capital formation, retraining, and the necessary funds.
I know it will be a difficult task because the national interests of individual companies are not aligned.

But since the competitive clash in the European Union is very ambiguous and sometimes risks being unfair, I think that in the end it is in the interest of all countries to have an effective impulse and community guidance to face together the increasingly aggressive global market.
Thank you. The energy crisis has and is making pay a very high price to all employment, to thousands of precarious workers, but also to stable and temporary workers, who are numerous in this sector.
The major steel groups are increasingly orienting themselves towards the Far East or the American continent, and this poses a major question about the direction of our development model.
I think that Europe should recover the idea that a manufacturing system like ours needs solid basic productions able to supply the European internal market.
Therefore, we must defend this sector, the role of a stable steel industry, which we will support, Commissioner, if we want to stop the industrial decline.

And I believe that we must get out of a dualism that is not outdated tonight here, but that is often heard in discussions on this sector, a dualism between the supporters of the environment and that of the workers, which is wrong because it does not show us a perspective of the future.
An industry that sees steel production as an integral part needs advanced production systems, concrete and balanced solutions that safeguard the different interests and needs.

It is therefore necessary a strong design, also European, that points to sustainability, which we must not, in my opinion, go back on, as a real added value with which we want to compete in the world, supporting investments as has been done.

Yes, thank you, Mr. President. As we have recalled in this Chamber, next December the United Nations agency dedicated to communication technologies and information will meet in Dubai for the World Conference on International Communications.

Therefore, I believe it is necessary to protect the role of the internet, the role that, above all, the internet can have in reviving economic growth, but not only, also to ensure opportunities for all.
I therefore hope that the Commission will work with the aim that Europe in Dubai is united and speak with a single voice.

Many are the controversial proposals presented at the negotiating table of the World Conference on International Telecommunications, in particular those that propose changes to the governance of the Internet that question the neutrality of the network, with negative repercussions for consumers.
In pericolo e quindi la libertà di internet o più precisamente la libertà di espressione e di protezione dei dati.
What some states have proposed would in fact allow a government to stick its nose not only in the communications of its citizens, but even in the data that transits on its networks.
The step from here to the limitation of freedom of expression and censorship is extremely short and therefore I believe it is in contradiction with the fundamental principles of the European Union.

Thank you, thank you, Mr. President. Overfishing is an unacceptable practice from an environmental point of view, as it threatens the sustainability of some shark species, which are already in danger.
Social and economic damage, since it involves the waste of a food good with commercial value, as well as from an ethical point of view, since it shows a total lack of respect for animal life.

Even though this practice has been banned since 2003 in the waters and for the European fleet, the Commission has decided to present a proposal that aims to eliminate the derogation from the ban on the removal of shark fins on board fishing vessels of the Union.

This proposal, in addition to further guaranteeing the protection that sharks need, will thus allow the European Union to actively contribute to the global effort underway to eradicate the cruel practice of cutting the fins of sharks, even in other parts of the world.
